ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
some of the timeless dilemmas of democracy and how to think about them
greater understanding of Tocqueville and Du Bois's writings
reconstructing and analyzing theories of democracy from difficult text

We read two authorsTocqueville and Du Boisclosely, in addition to some secondary scholarship. I learned how to formulate ideas about these authors, discuss them with my peers, and ask questions. I learned also how to write an extensive (around 30 page) research paper on a political philosophy topic, which was incredibly rewarding.
The Close reading skills and the skill for textual analysis.
I gained familiarity with Tocqueville's major work Democracy in America and Dubois' Black Reconstruction. The pace of the class allowed us read the texts in detail.
The most enduring insights were about federalism, the structural constraints on democracy, and the idea of political science or sociology.
I learned a great deal about Tocqueville and about Du Bois from taking this course.  I also learned how to more effectively write a research paper in the history of political thought.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: the texts and topics are incredibly significant
weaknesses: discussions lacked guidance lots of the time

Strengths: the instructors (wonderful co-teaching), the discussions, the texts, the paper writing workshops 
Weakness: the reading length would fluctuate from week to week, somewhat randomly (usually we would read 100 to 150 pages, but occasionally it went up to 400), so it was hard to predict how much time to spend on the class.
I really enjoyed the discussion of the course, but I do believe that the sessions can be more organized.

I wish the discussions were more organized. Because there were students from different disciplines the discussion often felt scattered. I wish the professors commented on students' thoughts more coherently or in a way that combined everyone's ideas to the readings. Maybe one professor should lead the discussion each week instead of both just facilitating the discussion. I also wished that the secondary literature was better; the syllabus should have recommended secondary readings on the list. Lastly, I wish the feedback on the final paper was better.
The syllabus was fabulous. Discussions could have been better structured with more clarity from instructors about the questions on the table.

The choice of readings and the abundant support for writing the research paper were both strengths of this course.  I believe the course would have been strengthened, however, if we had focused more heavily on Democracy in America and Black Reconstruction in America as opposed to other writings by the authors, preferably reading all of both books.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if they want a very grounded, real political theory class

Absolutely. This was one of the best classes I've taken at Yale. The readings, first of all, are amazing, and it's rare to be able to put Tocqueville and Du Bois in such close conversation. The professors are also incredible: they made insightful points, engaged students, and facilitated conversation. I loved that it was co-taught, because we could hear the professors explore thoughts with each other and hear different perspectives on the same question. The research paper, though daunting, was incredibly rewarding in the end. Everyone in the class was also very committed to learning and understanding the texts, which made for a vibrant seminar atmosphere. Most weeks, the only work is the reading and, based on which option you choose, your only assignment might be your research paper. There is a lot of reading, but it's doable if you treat it like the assignment for that class, and I would urge you to do so: this is a class where, as with many things, you get out what you put in. I really hope Prof. Oskian and Prof. Nakhimovsky co-teach a class again! If they do, please take it.
I would recommend it for the professors and the texts.
I would recommend this course to another student.  Tocqueville and Du Bois are enormously deep and incisive thinkers about America, and this course immerses you in their thought.
